gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers refer to specific people, mapping to the Individual scale.; Organizational: FMCG product development represents a function within a single company or organization, mapping to the Organizational scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumers' concerns about health and well-being are causing FMCG product development to react.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states a causal relationship where consumers' (Individual scale) concerns influence FMCG product development (Organizational scale). This establishes a clear cross-scale interaction. Only two distinct scales were identified.

Full Paragraph Text: Malnutrition – under and over nutrition – is an issue affecting the industry in both emerging and developed markets. This is creating a trend toward the manufacture of healthier food products, which either have fortified ingredients to improve dietary quality or address other dietary-related complaints such as unhealthy cholesterol levels.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition affecting both emerging and developed markets represents a societal-level health issue across different regions and populations; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The food industry as a whole responding by manufacturing healthier products represents sector-level action across multiple organizations
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Societal malnutrition issues drive food industry to manufacture healthier products.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly establishes causality where a societal health problem (malnutrition) is driving industry-wide behavioral change in product manufacturing. This represents a clear cross-scale interaction from societal conditions to sector-level response.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition is a societal-level health issue.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: ‘The industry’ and an industry-wide trend indicate sector-level dynamics.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Malnutrition drives an industry trend toward manufacturing healthier food products.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states that malnutrition affects the industry and creates a sector-wide trend. It does not explicitly state firm-level actions beyond this trend, so only a societal-to-sector link is included.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: The food industry is responding to malnutrition trends.; Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition is a societal issue affecting populations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Malnutrition influences the food industry to create healthier products.
o4_mini: Rationale: The text explicitly states that malnutrition affects the industry, indicating a causal influence from the societal level to the inter-organizational level. No other distinct scales were present.
gemini2.5: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Malnutrition, a broad societal health issue affecting populations across markets.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to 'the industry' and 'a trend' as collective phenomena or patterns across multiple organizations within the food sector.; Organizational: The 'manufacture' of healthier food products is an action undertaken by individual companies (organizations).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational] Societal malnutrition creates a trend in the food industry, influencing individual organizations to manufacture healthier products.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph outlines a causal chain where malnutrition (Environmental and Societal) explicitly 'creates a trend' within the food industry (Inter-Organizational / Sector). This sector-wide trend then strongly implies an influence on the specific 'manufacture' actions of individual companies (Organizational). All identified links involve different hierarchical scales as per the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: Women play a pivotal role in the FMCG market, controlling the majority of purchasing decisions. The promotion of women’s rights and opportunities has clear long-term implications for the FMCG market in terms of product development and innovation. Significant developments such as the UN’s new Sustainable Development Goals are expected to accelerate these opportunities.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: UN's Sustainable Development Goals represent a societal-level policy framework that influences broader systems; Inter-Organizational / Sector: FMCG market represents a sector-wide system involving multiple organizations and their collective product development and innovation activities
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] UN's SDGs expected to accelerate FMCG market opportunities for product development.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph establishes a clear causal link where UN's Sustainable Development Goals (societal-level policy) are expected to accelerate opportunities in the FMCG market (sector-level). While women's purchasing power is mentioned, no explicit causal mechanism is described between individual women and other scales.
gpt5: Scales: Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector
gpt5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The UN’s new Sustainable Development Goals are a single organization’s initiative.; Environmental and Societal: Promotion of women’s rights and opportunities reflects societal-level policies and norms.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The FMCG market is a sector involving multiple organizations.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector] UN SDGs boost women’s rights opportunities, which in turn shape FMCG sector product development and innovation.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states societal promotion of women’s rights influences the FMCG market, and that UN SDGs accelerate these societal opportunities. We include two cross-scale causal links forming a chain from UN to society to the sector.
o4_mini: Links: Individual -> Organizational | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as consumers making purchasing decisions.; Organizational: FMCG market as a specific industry.; Environmental and Societal: UN's Sustainable Development Goals impacting societal norms and opportunities.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Women influence FMCG market decisions, shaped by societal goals like the UN's SDGs.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links demonstrate how individual women's purchasing power affects organizational product strategies, while societal-level initiatives like the UN's SDGs create broader opportunities for the FMCG sector.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: 'Women' refers to specific people or informal groups.; Environmental and Societal: 'FMCG market' is an economic system/sector. 'Promotion of women’s rights and opportunities' and 'UN’s new Sustainable Development Goals' represent societal trends and global norms/frameworks, respectively.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] Women's individual purchasing decisions directly influence the broader FMCG market's dynamics.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The only explicit cross-scale interaction identified is from Individual (women) to Environmental and Societal (FMCG market), as women's control over purchasing decisions directly shapes the market. While the UN is Organizational, its 'Sustainable Development Goals' are classified as Environmental and Societal due to their nature as global norms/frameworks; therefore, their influence on 'opportunities' (also Environmental and Societal) constitutes a same-scale interaction. Similarly, the influence of 'promotion of women’s rights' (Environmental and Societal) on the 'FMCG market' (Environmental and Societal) is also a same-scale interaction.

Full Paragraph Text: The trend is being driven in developed and also emerging markets where mobile phones are proving to be one of the most effective ways of delivering advertising to individuals, particularly in the most remote rural locations. For instance, large parts of rural India have no, or very limited, access to television, print or radio. However, mobile phone penetration and usage is high. As a result, Unilever has launched Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station in India, which delivers radio content to mobile phones through the simple mechanism of giving a missed call.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific company that launched a mobile radio station service; Individual: People in rural locations who receive advertising content through mobile phones via missed calls
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever delivers advertising content to rural individuals through mobile radio service.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear causal relationship where Unilever (organizational scale) actively delivers advertising content to individuals in rural areas through their mobile radio station service. This represents explicit cross-scale causality from company action to individual reception of content.
gpt5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual | Environmental and Societal -> Individual
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Market conditions and infrastructure: high mobile penetration and limited TV/print/radio in rural India.; Organizational: Unilever launching the Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station.; Individual: Individuals in remote rural locations receiving advertising/content on mobile phones.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] Market media conditions drive Unilever’s mobile radio launch, which then delivers advertising content to individuals.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties rural media access and mobile penetration to Unilever’s launch, and states that mobile phones effectively deliver advertising to individuals. This yields Env/Soc -> Org and Org -> Ind, plus a direct Env/Soc -> Ind effect. Three scales are used clearly and minimally.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Individuals in rural areas are the recipients of mobile advertising.; Organizational: Unilever is an organization that is implementing a mobile radio service.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever's mobile radio service targets individuals in rural areas for advertising.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because Unilever's organizational action of launching a mobile radio service directly impacts individuals in rural India by providing them with content through their mobile phones.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Individual | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'individuals' as the specific people receiving content/advertising.; Organizational: Refers to 'Unilever' as a single company and its 'Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station' as an organizational initiative.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'mobile phones' as a widespread societal technology/infrastructure, and 'developed and emerging markets' and 'rural India' as societal-level contexts.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Societal mobile phone prevalence drives organizational action, which leverages the societal mobile phone system to reach individuals with content.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how the widespread use of mobile phones (Environmental and Societal) influences an organization's strategy (Unilever, Organizational) and how this strategy then leverages the mobile phone system to reach individuals (Individual). All three identified scales are explicitly linked with clear causal language.

Full Paragraph Text: This mobile channel provides content including Bollywood movie songs, dialogues and jokes that can be interspersed with Unilever brand advertising. Data and analytics are extensively used to vary content to make it relevant and interesting. The channel reaches approximately 10 million people without a TV in Bihar and Jharkhand states, making it one of the largest media channels in these regions. The channel had 29.5 million users by the end of December 2014, helping increase spontaneous awareness of Unilever brands.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company using the mobile channel for brand advertising and analytics; Individual: The 10 million people and 29.5 million users who consume the content and develop brand awareness
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever's mobile channel advertising increases brand awareness among millions of individual users.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how Unilever (organizational scale) uses its mobile channel to influence individual users' brand awareness. This represents a direct causal relationship from organizational marketing strategy to individual consumer awareness outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Users/people engaging with the mobile channel; Organizational: Unilever brands (brand awareness as an org-level outcome)
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Users of the channel helped increase spontaneous awareness of Unilever brands.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states that the large user base helped increase awareness of Unilever brands, a cross-scale effect from individuals to an organization. Other statements (reach, content variation) lack explicit cross-scale causal effects.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: The channel reaches individuals in Bihar and Jharkhand.; Organizational: Unilever is a brand that is advertising through the channel.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] The mobile channel influences brand awareness for Unilever among individuals in Bihar and Jharkhand.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the channel's reach to individuals directly contributes to increased awareness of Unilever brands, demonstrating a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to specific people or 'users' (10 million people, 29.5 million users) and their cognitive state ('spontaneous awareness').; Organizational: Refers to a single organization (mobile channel, Unilever brands/advertising) and its internal tools/activities ('data and analytics').; Environmental and Societal: Refers to societal-level systems (the geographical 'Bihar and Jharkhand states' and the broader 'media channels in these regions' as an industry landscape).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] An organizational mobile channel reaches and influences individuals' awareness while also impacting its position within the regional societal media landscape.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how an Organizational entity (the mobile channel) directly impacts Individual users by reaching them and increasing their brand awareness. Furthermore, the channel's operational scale also defines its standing within the broader Environmental and Societal media landscape of the regions. All identified scales and links are explicitly stated or strongly implied by causal verbs in the text.

Full Paragraph Text: Acting alone Unilever can only do so much to make sustainable living commonplace. Acting in partnership with others it can help bring about transformational change at a societal level to tackle the world’s major social, environmental and economic issues. By adopting a leadership role, and working with governments, NGOs, suppliers and others, we are influencing change on a bigger scale, with a much bigger prize for the business on offer. We are deepening our efforts in three areas where we have scale, influence and resources to create transformational change: deforestation; sustainable agriculture and smallholder farmers; and water, sanitation and hygiene.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company taking leadership actions and working with partners; Environmental and Societal: Governments, NGOs, and societal-level transformational change being influenced
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever influences societal-level change by partnering with governments and NGOs.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) causally influencing transformational change at the societal level (Environmental and Societal) through leadership and partnerships. Only one clear cross-scale link is present.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company taking actions (adopting leadership, working with others).; Environmental and Societal: Text states change at a societal level on social, environmental, and economic issues.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever’s leadership and partnerships drive transformational change at the societal level.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states Unilever’s actions influence societal-level change. Mentions of partners indicate collaborators, but the clearest explicit cross-scale causal link is from the company to societal outcomes, so only two scales are used.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is acting as an organization to influence change.; Environmental and Societal: The changes being targeted are at a societal level, addressing major social, environmental, and economic issues.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's partnerships aim for societal-level change in sustainability.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as Unilever, as an organization, influences societal-level changes through partnerships. No other distinct scales were present in the text.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual:  'smallholder farmers' are specific groups of people.; Organizational:  'Unilever', 'NGOs', and 'suppliers' are specific organizations.; Environmental and Societal:  'societal level', 'governments', and 'world’s major social, environmental and economic issues' represent societal-level systems and challenges.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever (Organizational) influences both societal-level systems (Environmental and Societal) and individual groups like smallholder farmers (Individual).
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) initiating actions that lead to transformational change at a societal level (Environmental and Societal). It also states that Unilever's efforts directly aim to create change for smallholder farmers (Individual). These represent distinct cross-scale causal influences. No more than three distinct scales were identified with explicit causal links.

Full Paragraph Text: Delivering our business goals requires Unilever to recruit, develop and retain the right talent. We are determined to help all our people to be the best they can be, to help fulfil their potential and the potential of the business. Training and development are crucial at all levels and we strive to create a working environment that respects the human rights and interests of all our employees. Ensuring gender equality is a fundamental part of our approach while our Purpose of making sustainable living commonplace is a commitment that our people can engage with every day and make a reality through their work.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'all our people', 'employees', and individual talent that needs to be recruited, developed and retained; Organizational: Refers to Unilever as a company with business goals, training programs, working environment policies, and organizational Purpose
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Unilever's business goals drive talent development while employee potential fulfillment contributes to business success.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a bidirectional relationship where Unilever's organizational needs drive individual talent development, and individual employee fulfillment contributes back to organizational potential. Both causal directions are explicitly stated in the text.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Employees/’our people’ are specific persons affected and acting through their work.; Organizational: Unilever is a single company setting goals, approaches, and work environment.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Employees’ work makes Unilever’s purpose real, while Unilever’s goals require recruiting and developing employees.

Full Paragraph Text: We also made progress against our Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) commitment to improve opportunities for women with the Dove Self-Esteem project, which has already reached over 15 million people. The brand partnered with the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts to launch the ‘Free Being Me’ Girl Guides badge awarded to girls taking part in education on common body myths. Also working to improve livelihoods, Lifebuoy soap continues to drive the largest handwashing behavioural change programme in the world, having reached 257 million people in more than 16 countries between 2010 and 2014.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever is one of the world’s biggest buyers of palm oil as a raw material for use in a number of our Foods and Personal Care brands. Palm oil is recognised as one of the four major commodities driving deforestation, which contributes up to 15% of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is identified as a single company that purchases palm oil as raw material for its brands; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions represent environmental systems at the societal/global level
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's palm oil purchasing contributes to deforestation and global greenhouse gas emissions.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph establishes a clear causal chain where Unilever (organizational actor) purchases palm oil, which contributes to deforestation that drives environmental impacts. This represents explicit cross-scale causality from organizational purchasing decisions to environmental outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: “Palm oil” as a major commodity denotes a sector-level system spanning many organizations.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation and global greenhouse gas emissions are environmental/societal systems.
gpt5: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal] Commodities like palm oil drive deforestation.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links the commodity sector to deforestation. Unilever’s purchasing is descriptive with no stated causal effect, and deforestation to GHG emissions is same-scale, so excluded.

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's palm oil sourcing impacts deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as Unilever's actions in sourcing palm oil directly contribute to environmental issues like deforestation and emissions, establishing a clear cross-scale interaction.

While Unilever (Organizational) is mentioned as a major buyer, the text does not explicitly state a causal influence from Unilever's specific buying actions to cross-scale effects. Only two distinct scales were identified with an explicit causal link, which is within the allowed limit of three.

Full Paragraph Text: In June 2014 Unilever, along with fellow members of the Consumer Goods Forum, called on heads of state for a binding global climate change deal. In September 2014 we helped facilitate the New York Declaration on Forests at the UN Climate Summit where more than 170 governments, companies and NGOs pledged to cut forest loss by half by 2020, end it by 2030 and restore 350 million hectares of degraded land.

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear chain where Unilever participates in the Consumer Goods Forum, which then influences government policy. This creates two distinct cross-scale links in the causal chain. All three scales are necessary to capture the full hierarchical interaction described.

Full Paragraph Text: Also in the same month, Unilever and the World Resources Institute announced a partnership aimed at increasing transparency in agricultural commodity supply chains. This will enable Unilever and our suppliers to use the Global Forest Watch Commodities platform to monitor forest cover change around commodity supply areas and processing facilities such as palm oil mills.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s work in moving from commitment to action in combating deforestation has been recognised. In November, we were ranked joint first for corporate action on tackling deforestation in our sector by CDP, formerly the Carbon Disclosure Project. The CDP report was produced on behalf of 240 investors, who together represent US $15 trillion in assets, and analysed the disclosures of 152 companies from around the world. It said: “Companies that regularly respond to CDP’s forests program are now identifying many more opportunities available to them, including securing their supply chain against the risks associated with deforestation and commodity sourcing. This in turn is helping to secure shareholder value.”
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company taking action on deforestation and being evaluated by CDP; Environmental and Societal: 240 investors representing $15 trillion in assets collectively influencing corporate behavior through CDP evaluation
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Investors collectively influence corporate deforestation action through CDP rankings.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph shows capital market actors (240 investors with $15 trillion) influencing individual company behavior through CDP's evaluation system. This creates a clear cross-scale interaction from societal-level capital markets to organizational action.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: ‘Securing their supply chain’ refers to cross-organization supply chain dynamics.; Environmental and Societal: ‘Shareholder value’ pertains to capital markets and societal-level financial outcomes.
gpt5: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal] Securing supply chains is said to help secure shareholder value.
gpt5: Rationale: The passage explicitly links supply chain security to shareholder value. A potential org-level precursor (companies responding to CDP) was omitted to keep unique scales to two.

Full Paragraph Text: On a global level Unilever is working hard to drive transparency in the palm oil supply chain. We now have visibility of about 1,800 crude palm oil mills, representing around two thirds of all mills in the global palm oil industry. We can also demonstrate traceability to a consumer product, which five years ago appeared unachievable. This represents a considerable breakthrough for Unilever and the food industry generally.

Full Paragraph Text: We want to build on our progress in Europe by repeating the achievement internationally. One of the next steps is our new processing plant in Sei Mangke, Indonesia. The plant is a significant investment to source palm oil from known and certified sources for our global use.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 Unilever enhanced its Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) by introducing new pillars to its goal of enhancing livelihoods. These were: fairness in the workplace, where we will advance human rights across our operations and extended supply chain; opportunities for women, where we will empower 5 million women by 2020; and inclusive business, where we will have a positive impact on the lives of 5.5 million people by 2020.

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever (organizational level) implementing policy changes that explicitly target and influence its extended supply chain (inter-organizational level). The causality is clear through the stated goal to 'advance human rights across our operations and extended supply chain.'

gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever’s plan explicitly aims to empower millions of individuals.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Unilever will empower 5 million women, a direct organizational-to-individual causal effect. There is also an organizational-to-inter-organizational intent (advancing human rights across its supply chain), but it is omitted to keep unique scales to two.

Full Paragraph Text: Through our own supply chain, our suppliers and our NGO partners, we are providing help and training to 800,000 smallholders to enable them to adopt sustainable practices. This helps them to increase yields, increase profits, invest and become more competitive while Unilever benefits from better yields, sustainably produced crops and security of raw material supply. However, assessing the impact of our programmes on farmers’ livelihoods is a complex area and our challenge is to find a practical and cost-effective means to demonstrate this.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company, along with suppliers and NGO partners as distinct organizations providing training and support; Individual: 800,000 smallholder farmers who are specific people receiving training and adopting practices
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever and partners train 800,000 smallholder farmers to adopt sustainable practices.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes explicit causality where organizational actors (Unilever, suppliers, NGO partners) directly influence individual actors (smallholder farmers) through training programs. While there are mutual benefits mentioned, the primary causal flow is from organizations providing training to individuals adopting practices.

Full Paragraph Text: In February 2014 we signed a five-year partnership with the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) to improve the livelihoods of smallholder farmers. Signed by IFAD President Kanayo F Nwanze and our CEO, Paul Polman, the partnership aims to help improve food security, by raising agricultural productivity and linking farmers to markets.

The causality is direct - the organizational partnership creates interventions designed to improve individual farmer outcomes through productivity increases and market linkages.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we published our Responsible Sourcing Policy (RSP). The RSP embodies our commitment to conduct business with integrity, openness, and respect for universal human rights and core labour principles. The RSP breaks new ground by defining a ‘continuous improvement ladder’ to help our suppliers move from a base level of ‘do no harm’ to ‘good practice’ and ultimately up to ‘best practice’ and as such is intended progressively to replace our Supplier Code in our dealings with key suppliers. The new code has been introduced to the supply base through communications and engagement from Procurement, and also through targeted events in critical markets such as Brazil, China and Vietnam.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company publishing the RSP policy and their Procurement department conducting communications and engagement; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply base and suppliers that are being influenced by the new policy implementation
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Company implements RSP policy to guide suppliers through continuous improvement ladder.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how the company (Organizational) is causally influencing its suppliers and supply base (Inter-Organizational / Sector) through the implementation of the RSP policy and targeted engagement activities. This represents a clear cross-scale hierarchical interaction where organizational policy drives sector-level change.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company (and its Procurement unit) publishes and introduces the RSP.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply base (collection of suppliers) receiving the code.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The company’s RSP is introduced to the supply base via Procurement and targeted events.
gpt5: Rationale: Text explicitly states the organization introduced its code to the supply base, a cross-scale effect. Other mentions (helping individual suppliers) are intra-organizational scale and excluded to maintain cross-scale validity.

Other interactions in the paragraph were either same-scale or descriptive, lacking explicit cross-scale causality.

Full Paragraph Text: Our partnership with Nature Source Genetics uses plant breeding to meet global demand while supporting communities that rely on the crop for income. The aim is to enhance productivity, quality and overall sustainability, and help stem any decline in crop diversity that could limit its ability to withstand drought, disease and pests.

Full Paragraph Text: In his first Independence Day address in 2014, Narendra Modi, India’s new Prime Minister, made a commitment that by 2019 every Indian would have access to a toilet. The promise highlights that about 2.5 billion people globally are without access to adequate sanitation, good hygiene and safe drinking water. There are still 46 countries in the world where less than half the population has access to adequate sanitation facilities. 800,000 children die every year from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water, and poor sanitation and hygiene.
claude4: Links: Individual -> Environmental and Societal | Environmental and Societal -> Individual
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Narendra Modi as a specific person making a commitment, and children dying from water-related diseases; Environmental and Societal: Government policy commitment to provide sanitation access to all Indians, and global sanitation systems affecting population health
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] PM's toilet commitment becomes policy while poor sanitation kills 800,000 children yearly.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph shows bidirectional causality: Modi's individual commitment drives government policy, while societal sanitation failures directly cause individual deaths. The Environmental and Societal -> Individual link is most critical as it represents the core problem being addressed.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Unsafe water, poor sanitation and hygiene are societal/environmental conditions.; Individual: Children experiencing mortality from diarrhoea.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Individual] Unsafe water and poor sanitation/hygiene cause child deaths.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly attributes child mortality to unsafe water and poor sanitation/hygiene, a societal/environmental cause impacting individuals. No other explicit cross-scale causal effects are stated.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to the 800,000 children affected by diarrhoea.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to the global sanitation crisis and the commitment made by the Prime Minister.
o4_mini: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Individual] Modi's commitment to sanitation aims to improve health outcomes for children affected by poor sanitation.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the societal issue of inadequate sanitation directly impacts individual health, particularly in children suffering from diarrhoea.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: The 'Prime Minister' (representing the government) and '46 countries' refer to states/governments, which are societal-level systems. 'Unsafe water, poor sanitation and hygiene' represent societal-level conditions.; Individual: 'Every Indian', '2.5 billion people globally', 'population', and '800,000 children' refer to specific people or aggregates of people.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Individual] The Prime Minister's commitment aims to provide sanitation for individuals, while unsafe societal conditions lead to individual deaths, highlighting critical cross-scale impacts.
gemini2.5: Rationale: Two explicit cross-scale links were identified. The first describes a government's commitment (Environmental and Societal) to improve living conditions for individuals. The second details how poor societal conditions (Environmental and Societal) directly cause negative health outcomes for individuals. Only two distinct scales were necessary to represent these interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: Transformational change is needed to combat these issues. Unilever is uniquely placed to help because of our expertise in consumer behaviour change, our global reach and our portfolio of health and hygiene brands, including Domestos, Lifebuoy and Pureit, our water purifier. However, bringing about widespread, sustainable behaviour change is not something we can do alone, so we need to work closely with governments, NGOs, academia and funding partners to increase our reach and impact.

This represents a clear cross-scale interaction where the company recognizes it must engage with broader societal actors to amplify its impact.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'consumer behaviour' which represents actions of specific people.; Organizational: Represents 'Unilever' as a single company.; Environmental and Societal: Encompasses 'governments' (explicitly societal-level) and, to adhere to the 3-scale limit, 'NGOs, academia and funding partners' are grouped here as broader societal-level systems or sectors that influence widespread change.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we committed to help 25 million people gain improved access to a toilet by 2020. By helping people who don’t have a toilet to get one and by promoting the benefits of using a clean toilet, we will open new markets and drive demand for our products.

The company's commitment creates a causal pathway from organizational decision-making to individual welfare improvement.

Full Paragraph Text: Lifebuoy has long championed the health benefits of handwashing with soap and aims to change the hygiene behaviour of 1 billion consumers across Asia, Africa and Latin America. To achieve this ambition, we have to find ways to scale up our programmes: we need to develop lower cost, mass-scale behaviour change approaches and expand our partnerships and co-investment models. Lifebuoy has enjoyed four years of sequential double-digit sales growth.

Full Paragraph Text: Women are the majority of our consumer base and their purchasing decisions are pivotal to our growth. They are strongly represented in our agricultural supply chains and in the distribution of our brands to market. At the same time we are a large employer and need the best available talent to succeed in our business goals.

Full Paragraph Text: For instance in Sekondi, Ghana, a three-day workshop by the Unilever Ghana Foundation taught 60 women how to think and act like entrepreneurs, coached them in bookkeeping procedures, and cash and working capital management. This brings to more than 700 the number of women trained in Ghana and supports Unilever’s commitment to empower 5 million women by 2020.

Full Paragraph Text: To date we have trained and recruited more than 3,400 women from nearly 1,100 villages in Pakistan as part of the Guddi Baji (‘Good Sister’) programme. This initiative helps increase sales as well as generating sustainable incomes for women through the sale of Unilever hygiene and personal care brands and through the provision of beauty services to other local women.

Full Paragraph Text: Our programmes also help young women and men. Our Wall’s team has developed a youth employment programme, known as ‘Feet on the Street’, to help tackle the youth jobless rate in Europe while driving our growth agenda by bringing ice cream to the streets. Wall’s provides tools and equipment, such as trikes or push carts and freezers, to enable a micro-entrepreneur to run his or her own mini-business selling ice cream and also to provide young people with their first job experience. In Portugal, Spain and Italy, 250 seasonal jobs were also created to enhance livelihoods while boosting ice cream sales. Our ambition is to have 50,000 micro-entrepreneurs by 2020 with a potential contribution to turnover of more than €100 million.

Full Paragraph Text: Domestos has led our efforts on sanitation in partnership with UNICEF. Our brand, together with the Unilever Foundation, supports UNICEF’s Community Approaches to Total Sanitation (CATS) programme which aims to eliminate open defecation by changing people’s behaviour and promoting demand for sanitation. Domestos contributed 5% of its average proceeds from specially marked bottles on sale in certain markets to UNICEF. Domestos sales continue to grow strongly and were up 7.3% in 2014.

This represents a direct cross-scale influence from organizational to individual level.

Full Paragraph Text: Access to training and skills for women and to advancing women’s rights. A key aspect of this has been our safety programme for women and girls, with the involvement of men and boys, which we have begun at our tea plantation in Kericho, Kenya, in response to reports of sexual harassment in 2013. The programme is being rolled out to other locations. More information on our progress on women’s rights is in the Society section on pages 22 to 24, with full details to be published in our Sustainable Living Report 2014 which will be found on www.unilever.com/sustainable-living in May 2015.

Full Paragraph Text: These priorities still underpin everything we do. Our people are also the embodiment of the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) – without their commitment and belief, the business could not achieve the plan’s three main goals of improving health and well-being, reducing our environmental impact and enhancing livelihoods. More than 75% of employees say they can contribute to the USLP in their roles and help realise our Vision.

They are each set a demanding case study to run one of our brands, which in 2014 was TRESemmé, with a strong sustainability theme.

gpt5: Rationale: The passage explicitly attributes engagement with individuals (‘future leaders’) to an organizational program (Future Leaders League). Other actions (universities sending teams) duplicate the same scale pair, so only the clearest link is kept.

These Individuals then causally interact with Organizational assets (running a brand). Additionally, an Environmental and Societal factor (sustainability theme) explicitly shapes the content of the Organizational task given to the individuals. The selected scales (Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal) are the only ones clearly and explicitly involved in cross-scale interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: All participants interact with senior management, including our CEO, Paul Polman, and receive first-hand insights into business and leadership. They learn what it’s like to contribute to a business and build ideas.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Participants are specific people engaging in learning activities; Organizational: Senior management and CEO Paul Polman represent the company's organizational leadership structure
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Senior management provides direct insights and learning experiences to program participants.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear causal relationship where organizational leadership (senior management, CEO) actively influences individuals (participants) by providing insights and learning opportunities. This represents a direct cross-scale interaction from organizational to individual level.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Senior management/CEO is a formal unit within an organization.; Individual: Participants are individual people receiving insights and learning.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Senior management interaction gives participants first-hand insights and learning.
gpt5: Rationale: The text states participants interact with senior management and receive first-hand insights, causing learning. This is an explicit organizational-to-individual influence; no other scales are causally involved.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Participants are specific people engaging in the interaction.; Organizational: Senior management, including the CEO, represents a formal organizational structure.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Participants gain insights from senior management, influencing their understanding of business dynamics.
o4_mini: Rationale: The interaction between participants (individuals) and senior management (organizational) shows a clear causal influence. No other scales are present, keeping the focus on these two.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'All participants' who are specific people receiving insights and learning.; Organizational: Refers to 'senior management' and 'our CEO, Paul Polman' which are formal units or individuals acting within a single organization ('business').
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Senior management provides first-hand insights to participants, influencing their learning.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states that 'senior management' (Organizational) interacts with and provides 'first-hand insights' to 'All participants' (Individual), establishing a clear causal influence from the organizational level to the individual level. This is the only explicit cross-scale interaction identified, as other actions like 'learn' and 'contribute' describe individual-level processes or intentions, not direct causal influences on another scale within the given text.

Full Paragraph Text: Guided and supported by some of the world’s top thought leaders, UL2020 identifies some of Unilever’s most critical challenges and asks small, diverse leadership teams to create solutions. These projects, called Purpose to Impact Initiatives, are structured programmes that deliver individual and wider business development consistent with our commercial and social aims.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Small, diverse leadership teams are groups of specific people working together; Organizational: Unilever as a company with its commercial and social aims, and UL2020 as a formal program
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] UL2020 program tasks leadership teams to create solutions that deliver business development.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear bidirectional relationship where Unilever's organizational program (UL2020) directs individual teams to work on solutions, and these teams then deliver results back to the organizational level. The most critical link is the organizational directive to individuals since it initiates the process.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Mentions 'top thought leaders' and 'individual development' affecting/affected by programs.; Organizational: UL2020 and Unilever’s programmes/projects are organizational entities/actions.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Thought leaders guide UL2020, and the resulting programs deliver individual development.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties individual thought leaders’ guidance to UL2020’s organizational activities and states that the programs deliver individual development. Only Individual and Organizational scales are implicated.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: The small, diverse leadership teams consist of specific individuals working on projects.; Organizational: Unilever is a single organization that is addressing its critical challenges.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Leadership teams at Unilever create solutions for the organization’s challenges.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the actions of the individual leadership teams directly influence the organizational goals of Unilever. No other scales were present in the text.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'top thought leaders' as specific external experts providing guidance, and 'individual development' as the growth of specific people participating in the programs.; Organizational: Refers to 'UL2020' as an internal program, 'Unilever' as a company, 'leadership teams' as formal internal units, and 'Purpose to Impact Initiatives' as structured programs within the company.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] External thought leaders influence an organizational program, which then fosters individual development.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes two explicit cross-scale interactions. First, 'top thought leaders' (Individual) 'guided and supported' the 'UL2020' program (Organizational). Second, 'Purpose to Impact Initiatives' (Organizational programs) 'deliver individual development'. Only two distinct scales (Individual, Organizational) were involved, requiring no scale limitation.

Full Paragraph Text: Every year, our people nominate ‘Unilever heroes’ for work that brings our Purpose to life. Anila Gopal, Global Social Mission Manager for Lifebuoy, based in India, is a Unilever hero. She is helping to run the world’s largest handwashing behaviour change programme that demonstrates how using soap could help save children from deadly, but preventable, diseases.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Anila Gopal is a specific person (Global Social Mission Manager) taking action to run a handwashing program; Organizational: Unilever as a company has a nomination system for 'Unilever heroes' and operates the Lifebuoy brand with its global handwashing program
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever nominates employee Anila Gopal as company hero for handwashing program work.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph shows Unilever (organizational) explicitly nominating and recognizing Anila Gopal (individual) through their hero program. While Anila runs a large-scale program, the causal relationship described is the company's recognition system affecting the individual employee.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Anila Gopal (a person) and children (people) are specific individuals.; Organizational: The Lifebuoy/Unilever handwashing programme is an organizational initiative.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] An individual helps run an organizational programme, which demonstrates benefits to children.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links an individual’s actions to operating an organizational programme, and the programme’s activities to effects on individuals (children). Only two scales are involved, satisfying cross-scale causality.
o4_mini: Links: Individual -> Organizational | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Anila Gopal is a specific person recognized for her contributions.; Organizational: Unilever is a specific organization that has a program led by Anila.; Environmental and Societal: The handwashing program aims to impact societal health outcomes.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Anila Gopal's role at Unilever influences societal health through a handwashing program.
o4_mini: Rationale: The links demonstrate how Anila's individual efforts within Unilever contribute to broader societal health outcomes. The detected scales include Individual, Organizational, and Environmental and Societal, but only the first two are directly linked in the context of her role.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Anila Gopal, 'our people', 'Unilever heroes', and 'children' are specific people or informal groups.; Organizational: The 'world’s largest handwashing behaviour change programme' is an initiative run by Lifebuoy/Unilever, representing a single organization's formal unit or action.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] An individual helps run an organizational program that, in turn, demonstrates how to impact individuals.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how Anila Gopal (Individual) contributes to an organizational programme, which then demonstrates a mechanism to save children (Individual). The chosen scales (Individual, Organizational) clearly capture these explicit cross-scale influences, with 'Environmental and Societal' elements (diseases) acting as context rather than direct causal agents in the stated interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: Elsewhere, over 2013-14, there has been a 51% reduction in the number of internal reports prepared for leadership teams, releasing time to focus on more productive activity. We also simplified the GPS which we ask all employees to complete annually, enabling us to cut the time individuals spent completing the survey significantly.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company/organization that reduced internal reports and simplified the GPS survey system; Individual: All employees who complete the annual GPS survey and spend time on it
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company simplified survey system, reducing time employees spend completing it.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes explicit organizational action (simplifying the GPS survey) that causally reduces the time burden on individual employees. This represents a clear cross-scale interaction from organizational policy to individual experience.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company simplifies the GPS survey and reduces internal reports.; Individual: Employees (individuals) spend less time completing the survey.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational-Individual] Simplifying the GPS by the company reduced the time employees spent on the survey.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states that the organization simplified the GPS, which cut individuals' survey time. The 'releasing time' from fewer reports lacks a clear individual-level subject, so it was excluded.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Employees are completing the GPS survey.; Organizational: Leadership teams are involved in the internal reports.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Employees' survey completion affects leadership teams' internal reports.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the simplification of the GPS survey for individuals directly influences the number of internal reports prepared for the organizational leadership teams, demonstrating a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: 'We' (the entity simplifying the GPS) refers to the organization; 'leadership teams' are formal internal units.; Individual: 'employees' and 'individuals' refer to specific people within the organization.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Organizational actions to simplify processes directly reduced time spent by individuals.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes how the organization's (Organizational) action of simplifying a survey ('the GPS') directly led to a reduction in time spent by employees ('individuals' - Individual). This demonstrates a clear causal influence from the organizational level down to the individual level. No other explicit cross-scale links were present.

Full Paragraph Text: In the supply chain we have taken a broad approach to building capabilities for our employees. This includes a host of skills development programmes for blue and white collar employees. Training in core skills is mandatory across 130 roles. Skill assessments are completed every two years and the data is used to understand and address specific gaps across roles, capabilities and geographies.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company implementing skills development programmes, mandatory training, and skill assessments across roles; Individual: Blue and white collar employees receiving training and undergoing skill assessments
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company implements mandatory training programs affecting employees across multiple roles.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear organizational initiative (skills development programmes, mandatory training, skill assessments) that directly impacts individual employees. The company's systematic approach to capability building creates a direct causal influence from the organizational level to individual workers.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company sets policies and programs (mandatory training, assessments, addressing gaps).; Individual: Employees (blue and white collar) who receive training and undergo assessments.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company mandates training and uses assessment data to build employee capabilities.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly states organizational policies and actions (mandatory training, data-driven gap addressing) that act on employees. Mentions of 'supply chain' are contextual and do not assert cross-scale causality beyond the organization-to-individual link.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The training and skill development programmes are specific to the organization.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The mention of the supply chain indicates a broader inter-organizational context.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] The organization's training initiatives influence the broader supply chain context.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the training programs for employees are explicitly stated as part of the supply chain, indicating a causal influence from the organizational level to the inter-organizational level.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Individual | Individual -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'our employees' and 'blue and white collar employees' as specific people participating in programs and assessments.; Organizational: Refers to 'we' (the entity managing the supply chain), representing a single organization implementing strategies and using data.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] The organization influences employees through capability building and mandatory training, and uses employee assessment data to address skill gaps.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly details how an organization (Organizational scale) implements initiatives like skills development and mandatory training, directly influencing its employees (Individual scale). Conversely, information from individual employee skill assessments creates data that directly informs the organization's strategy to address skill gaps, demonstrating a clear feedback loop. Only two scales, Individual and Organizational, were explicitly involved in these direct causal interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014, we introduced a step change in our Safe Travel programme. With more people on the road than ever before, including many in developing countries where there is a higher risk of car accidents, we released a revised and strengthened travel standard that includes programmes and strategies specifically targeted at high and medium risk locations. By the middle of 2015, we will also have in place a mandatory global ban on using all hand-held and hands-free mobile phone devices while driving on company business.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('we') that introduced the Safe Travel programme and implemented travel standards and mobile phone bans; Individual: Employees who must comply with the travel standards and mobile phone ban while driving on company business
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company implements travel standards and mobile phone ban affecting employee driving behavior.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes clear organizational policies (travel standards and mobile phone ban) that directly influence individual employee behavior while driving on company business. Both links represent the same directional relationship but involve different policy mechanisms.
gpt5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Societal conditions: more people on the road and higher accident risk in developing countries; Organizational: The company ('we') issuing standards and bans; Individual: Employees driving on company business subject to the ban
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] Societal traffic risk prompted the company’s new travel standard, and its phone-use ban constrains employee driving behavior.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties societal accident risk to the company releasing a revised standard, and it specifies a mandatory ban that affects employees’ driving behavior. These are direct cross-scale causal statements; no other clear cross-scale links are stated.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The Safe Travel programme is an initiative by an organization aimed at improving travel safety.; Environmental and Societal: The mention of developing countries and the risk of car accidents indicates a societal-level concern.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The Safe Travel programme targets safety improvements in high-risk locations.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the organizational initiative directly addresses societal safety concerns in developing countries, creating a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'people on the road' and implicitly 'drivers on company business' whose 'using mobile phone devices' is targeted by the ban.; Organizational: Refers to 'we' (the company), 'our Safe Travel programme', 'travel standard', 'programmes and strategies', and 'global ban'.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'developing countries' as a geographic context and 'higher risk of car accidents' as a societal safety concern and 'more people on the road' as a demographic trend.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Individual, Organizational] Societal conditions prompted the organization to implement a travel standard, which includes a ban directly impacting individual driver behavior.
gemini2.5: Rationale: Two explicit cross-scale causal links were identified. The first link demonstrates how societal and environmental factors (risk, demographics) motivate an organizational response. The second link shows a direct top-down influence where an organizational policy (the ban) directly changes individual behavior. These three scales (Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal) cover all actors explicitly mentioned in a causal relationship.

Full Paragraph Text: This year saw considerable advancement in our behavioural-based approach to health and safety, with 84% of our manufacturing and 38% of our non-manufacturing sites now having rolled out the first phase of the BeSafE programme. This includes training 79 master coaches and 91 trainers, who have in turn trained more than 1,840 employees.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company implementing the BeSafE programme across manufacturing and non-manufacturing sites; Individual: Master coaches, trainers, and employees who receive training as specific people within the organization
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Company's BeSafE programme rollout trains coaches and employees in health and safety.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a clear hierarchical interaction where the organizational-level BeSafE programme implementation directly causes training outcomes at the individual level (coaches, trainers, and employees). The causality is explicit through the rollout leading to specific training numbers.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company/sites rolled out the BeSafE programme and provided training.; Individual: Master coaches, trainers, and employees are specific people receiving/providing training.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The company’s BeSafE programme trained master coaches and trainers, influencing individual behavior/capability.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states the program trained specific people, a direct organizational-to-individual causal effect. We exclude the trainers training employees because it is individual-to-individual (same scale) and thus out of scope.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The BeSafE programme is implemented at the organizational level across manufacturing and non-manufacturing sites.; Individual: Employees are the individuals being trained as part of the programme.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The BeSafE programme's rollout at the organizational level influences employee training.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the organizational implementation of the BeSafE programme directly results in the training of individual employees. No other scales are present.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Refers to the company's 'manufacturing and non-manufacturing sites' and the 'BeSafE programme', which are units/initiatives within a single organization.; Individual: Refers to specific people such as 'master coaches and trainers' and 'employees'.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The organizational BeSafE program, implemented by sites, directly trained individual master coaches and trainers.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes the 'BeSafE programme' being rolled out by 'sites' (both Organizational scale elements). This programme explicitly 'includes training' specific 'master coaches and trainers' (Individual scale elements). This is a direct, explicit causal link from the Organizational scale to the Individual scale. While there is also an explicit link of 'master coaches and trainers' training 'employees', this is an Individual -> Individual interaction and therefore not included as per the protocol. Only two distinct scales (Organizational and Individual) were relevant for cross-scale links.

Full Paragraph Text: Women are Unilever’s core consumers, controlling nearly two thirds of consumer spending, so it’s important that we represent them in our workforce. In fact, 2014 marks five years since we began the process of building an agile and diverse Unilever and making sure we have the right gender balance throughout the organisation.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as consumers who control consumer spending decisions; Organizational: Unilever as a company implementing workforce diversity policies and organizational changes
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Women consumers' spending power drives Unilever's workforce diversity initiatives.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph establishes a clear causal link where individual consumer behavior (women controlling spending) explicitly influences organizational policy (Unilever's workforce diversity efforts). The company states this consumer influence is why representation is 'important' and drives their organizational changes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as specific consumers controlling spending; Organizational: Unilever adjusting workforce representation and gender balance
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Women consumers’ spending power drives Unilever to represent them in its workforce.
gpt5: Rationale: The text states consumer women’s control of spending, leading Unilever to prioritize representing them in its workforce. This is a direct causal link from individuals to the organization. No other cross-scale effects are explicitly described.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as consumers influence spending patterns.; Organizational: Unilever as an organization is working to represent these consumers in its workforce.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Women as consumers influence Unilever's workforce representation strategy.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists because the paragraph explicitly states that women, as core consumers, influence Unilever's approach to workforce diversity, creating a clear cross-scale interaction.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual:  'Women' are described as 'core consumers' and 'controlling consumer spending', which maps to specific people or informal groups.; Organizational:  'Unilever' is explicitly a single company, and 'workforce' refers to an internal unit within that organization.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Individual consumers' spending power explicitly influences Unilever's organizational efforts towards workforce representation.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph clearly establishes one cross-scale causal link. Women, as individual consumers with significant spending control, are presented as the reason ('so it's important') for Unilever's organizational decision to represent them in their workforce. This interaction moves from the Individual scale to the Organizational scale. No other explicit cross-scale links are present in the text, with the remainder describing internal organizational processes.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we paid particular attention to mental health initiatives. The rising incidence of mental ill health in the UK is reflected in our absence data. Help and support on nutrition, sleep, exercise and mindfulness all improve the day-to-day well-being of employees. A robust framework with support tools is now in place and is being rolled out across the organisation.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: The rising incidence of mental ill health in the UK represents a societal-level trend affecting the broader population; Organizational: The company implementing mental health initiatives, support frameworks, and organizational rollout represents organizational-level action
claude4: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] UK mental health trends prompt company to implement workplace wellness initiatives.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly establishes causality where a societal health trend (rising mental ill health in the UK) influences organizational response (mental health initiatives and support framework implementation). This represents a clear cross-scale interaction from societal level to organizational level.
gpt5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: “Rising incidence of mental ill health in the UK” is a societal-level trend.; Organizational: “Our absence data” and “framework with support tools… rolled out across the organisation” are company-level.; Individual: “Employees” and their “day-to-day well-being” are specific people.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] UK mental ill-health rises affect company absence data; company support initiatives improve employees’ well-being.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties UK-wide mental ill-health to the firm's absence data (societal -> organizational). It also states that organizational support improves employees’ well-being (organizational -> individual). No other cross-scale effects are explicit.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Employees' well-being is directly influenced by mental health initiatives.; Organizational: The organization implements a framework to support these initiatives.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The organization's mental health initiatives enhance individual employee well-being.
o4_mini: Rationale: The link exists as the organizational framework directly influences the well-being of individual employees. No other scales were present.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'employees' whose day-to-day well-being is improved by support.; Organizational: Refers to 'we', 'our absence data', 'the organisation', and the 'Help and support' provided by the entity.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to the 'rising incidence of mental ill health in the UK', a broader societal issue.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational, Individual] Societal mental health trends influence organizational data, prompting organizational support to improve individual employee well-being.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links societal mental health trends to organizational data, showing an Environmental and Societal -> Organizational influence. Furthermore, the organization's initiatives directly improve individual employee well-being, indicating an Organizational -> Individual causal interaction. These two distinct cross-scale links are clearly stated through verbs like 'reflected in' and 'improve'.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we strengthened the enhancing livelihoods ambition of the USLP. An integral part of this is our implementation of the UN Guiding Principle on Business and Human Rights and our public reporting on this. We also committed to enhancing access to training and skills for women and to advancing women’s rights. A key aspect of this has been our safety programme for women and girls, with the involvement of men and boys, which we have begun at our tea plantation in Kericho, Kenya, in response to reports of sexual harassment in 2013. The programme is being rolled out to other locations. More information on our progress on women’s rights is in the Society section on pages 22 to 24, with full details to be published in our Sustainable Living Report 2014 which will be found on www.unilever.com/sustainable-living in May 2015.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Reports of sexual harassment in 2013 represent individual-level experiences and complaints; Organizational: Unilever as a company implementing safety programmes and policy responses at their tea plantation

claude4: Rationale: The paragraph clearly describes how individual reports of sexual harassment in 2013 caused Unilever (organizational level) to respond by implementing a safety programme. This represents explicit cross-scale causality from individual experiences to organizational policy action.

gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Reports of sexual harassment led Unilever to start a safety programme at its Kericho tea plantation.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties individuals’ reports of harassment to the organization launching a safety programme. Other statements (e.g., implementing UN principles) lack explicit cross-scale causality, so were excluded.

Full Paragraph Text: And we are providing support through the Domestos Toilet Academy, a market-based model that improves sanitation in India and Vietnam. By the end of 2014 there were ten Domestos Toilet Academies open, eight in India and two in Vietnam. The Academies train entrepreneurs to form businesses supplying, installing and maintaining hygienic toilets. The initiative will train 250 entrepreneurs and supply 51,000 toilets by the end of 2015.
